title: Ticket #7177: Should transfer finished events have success/failure information?
description:
The transfer-finished events in the job log don't specify if the transfer completed successfully, but in at least one case (see below), appear even if the transfer failed.

I previously argued that transfer-finished events should appear even -- or perhaps especially -- for failed transfers; it's information that could be very useful, but we don't people (or programs) to have to infer it, for the same reason(s) that explicit transfer events are useful at all.

The obvious follow-up argument is that determining success or failure should also not require looking at other events.

I will have to investigate to see if the specific failure case that we know appears in the log is unique or not; there may be a counter-argument that we should instead make transfer-finished-and-failed events uniformly not appear in the log, and make the presence of an event signal success.

The obvious counter-argument may be identical in the case. ;)
remarks:
2019-Jul-31 16:05:45 by karpel:
The philosophical issue seems to be whether you should be able to determine a job's state uniquely from the last event you read, or whether you need to reconstruct its entire history to determine the current state.

In the log in question, we get a sequence like 

040 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 14:44:30 Entered queue to transfer output files
...
022 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 14:48:37 Job disconnected, attempting to reconnect
    Socket between submit and execute hosts closed unexpectedly
    Trying to reconnect to slot1_30@e273.chtc.wisc.edu <128.105.245.73:9618?addrs=128.105.245.73-9618&alias=e273.chtc.wisc.edu&noUDP&sock=startd_7113_813d_3>
...
040 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 14:48:37 Finished transferring output files
...
023 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 14:48:37 Job reconnected to slot1_30@e273.chtc.wisc.edu
    startd address: <128.105.245.73:9618?addrs=128.105.245.73-9618&alias=e273.chtc.wisc.edu&noUDP&sock=startd_7113_813d_3>
    starter address: <128.105.245.73:9618?addrs=128.105.245.73-9618&alias=e273.chtc.wisc.edu&noUDP&sock=starter_7716_5eb3_22739>
...
040 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 14:55:13 Entered queue to transfer output files
...
022 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 15:00:13 Job disconnected, attempting to reconnect
    Socket between submit and execute hosts closed unexpectedly
    Trying to reconnect to slot1_30@e273.chtc.wisc.edu <128.105.245.73:9618?addrs=128.105.245.73-9618&alias=e273.chtc.wisc.edu&noUDP&sock=startd_7113_813d_3>
...
040 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 15:00:13 Finished transferring output files
...
023 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 15:01:58 Job reconnected to slot1_30@e273.chtc.wisc.edu
    startd address: <128.105.245.73:9618?addrs=128.105.245.73-9618&alias=e273.chtc.wisc.edu&noUDP&sock=startd_7113_813d_3>
    starter address: <128.105.245.73:9618?addrs=128.105.245.73-9618&alias=e273.chtc.wisc.edu&noUDP&sock=starter_7716_5eb3_22739>
...
040 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 15:02:03 Entered queue to transfer output files
...
040 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 15:02:39 Started transferring output files
	Seconds spent in queue: 2395
...
040 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 15:02:42 Finished transferring output files
...
005 (8207717.000.000) 07/29 15:02:48 Job terminated.
	(1) Normal termination (return value 0)
		Usr 0 00:00:00, Sys 0 00:00:00  -  Run Remote Usage
		Usr 0 00:00:00, Sys 0 00:00:00  -  Run Local Usage
		Usr 0 00:00:00, Sys 0 00:00:00  -  Total Remote Usage
		Usr 0 00:00:00, Sys 0 00:00:00  -  Total Local Usage
	10730  -  Run Bytes Sent By Job
	10737418240  -  Run Bytes Received By Job
	10730  -  Total Bytes Sent By Job
	10737418240  -  Total Bytes Received By Job
	Partitionable Resources :    Usage  Request Allocated
	   Cpus                 :        0        1         1
	   Disk (KB)            : 10485797 11534336  11702622
	   Ioheavy              :                           0
	   Memory (MB)          :        1       50        50
...

There are gaps after the "finished transferring output files" events where you would expect the next event to be a "terminate" according some imagined state transition diagram that doesn't actually exist, but it will in fact be a "reconnect". The only way to know that is to look at previous events and realize that you didn't really finish transferring, the shadow just lost touch with the starter.

So... maybe there should be another file transfer event subtype, something like "transfer aborted"? Can the shadow actually tell the difference at the point that it writes this message?

2019-Jul-31 21:52:43 by bbockelm:
I don't understand what the philosophical question is about.

When a file transfer is complete, should we record its status (whether it was a success or failure)?

It seems to me that the answer is clearly "yes".

2019-Aug-06 12:32:22 by tlmiller:
ToddT is OK with either of always having an event that explicits identifies success or failure, or having an event whose presence signifies success and whose absence indicates failure.

I will see which one the code is currently trying to do. ;)

2019-Aug-27 13:11:31 by tlmiller:
The code currently "always" has an event, inasmuch as it does not distinguish between success and failure. If the file transfer is not queued, there will not be queuing event.
creator: tlmiller
